[[File:Global Map of Photovoltaic Power Potential.png|thumb|upright=1.5|Global photovoltaic power potential{{Cite web|url=https://globalsolaratlas.info/|title=Global Solar Atlas}}]] Many countries and territories have installed significant [[solar power]] capacity into their electrical grids to supplement or provide an alternative to [[conventional energy]] sources. Solar power plants use one of two technologies: * [[Photovoltaic]] (PV) [[Photovoltaic systems|systems]] use [[solar panel]]s, either on [[Rooftop photovoltaic power station|rooftops]] or in ground-mounted [[solar farm]]s, converting sunlight directly into electric power. * [[Concentrated solar power]] (CSP, also known as "concentrated solar thermal") plants use [[solar thermal energy]] to make steam, that is thereafter converted into electricity by a turbine. Worldwide [[growth of photovoltaics]] is extremely dynamic and varies strongly by country. As of 2020, there are at least 37 countries around the world with a cumulative PV capacity of more than one gigawatt. By the end of 2016, cumulative photovoltaic capacity increased by more than 75 [[gigawatt]] (GW) and reached at least 303 GW, sufficient to supply approximately 1.8 percent of the world's total [[electricity consumption]]. The top installers of 2016 were [[#China|China]], the [[#United States|United States]], and [[#India|India]].[https://www.greentechmedia.com/articles/read/iea-global-installed-pv-capacity-leaps-to-303-gw IEA: Global Installed PV Capacity Leaps to 303 Gigawatts], greentechmedia, Eric Wesoff, April 27, 2017 The available solar PV capacity in Honduras is now sufficient to supply 12.5% of the nation's electrical power while [[#Italy|Italy]], Germany and [[#Greece|Greece]] can produce between 7% and 8% of their respective domestic electricity consumption.[http://www.iea-pvps.org/fileadmin/dam/public/report/statistics/IEA-PVPS_-_A_Snapshot_of_Global_PV_-_1992-2016__1_.pdf 2016 Snapshot of Global Photovoltaic Markets], International Energy Agency, 2017{{cite web |title = Global Market Outlook for Solar Power 2015-2019 |url = http://www.solarpowereurope.org/fileadmin/user_upload/documents/Publications/Global_Market_Outlook_2015_-2019_lr_v23.pdf |website = www.solarpowereurope.org |publisher = Solar Power Europe (SPE), formerly known as EPIA – European Photovoltaic Industry Association |accessdate = 9 June 2015 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6ZA1o2aLo?url=http://www.solarpowereurope.org/fileadmin/user_upload/documents/Publications/Global_Market_Outlook_2015_-2019_lr_v23.pdf |archivedate = 9 June 2015 |url-status = dead }}{{cite web|url=http://www.iea-pvps.org/fileadmin/dam/public/report/technical/PVPS_report_-_A_Snapshot_of_Global_PV_-_1992-2014.pdf|title=Snapshot of Global PV 1992-2014|date=30 March 2015|website=iea-pvps.org|publisher=International Energy Agency — Photovoltaic Power Systems Programme|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6XPpb1fai?url=http://www.iea-pvps.org/index.php?id=92&eID=dam_frontend_push&docID=2430|archivedate=30 March 2015|url-status=live}} After an almost two decade long hiatus, [[Concentrated solar power#Deployment around the world|deployment of CSP]] resumed in 2007. However, the design for several new projects is being changed to cheaper photovoltaics.{{cite web |url=http://cleantechnica.com/2014/02/27/csp-fallen-wayside-may-come-back-big-2020/ |title=CSP Has Fallen By The Wayside – But May Come Back Big By 2020 |website=[[CleanTechnica]] |date=27 February 2014}} Most [[List of solar thermal power stations|operational CSP stations]] are located in [[#Spain|Spain]] and the United States, while [[List of photovoltaic power stations|large solar farms]] using photovoltaics are being constructed in an expanding list of geographic regions. As of January 2017, the largest solar power plants in the world are the 850 MW [[Longyangxia Dam Solar Park]] in China for PV and the 377 MW [[Ivanpah Solar Power Facility]] in the United States for CSP. {{Horizontal TOC|nonum=yes}} == Global deployment figures == ===Solar photovoltaics (PV)=== {{see also|Growth of photovoltaics}} {| style="margin: 1px auto;top:right" |- | {{Image frame |width = 260 |align = center |pos = top |content =

The distribution of solar resources across Africa is fairly uniform, with more than 85% of the continent's landscape receiving at least 2,000 kWh/(m² year). A study indicates that a solar generating facility covering just 0.3% of the area comprising North Africa could supply all of the energy required by the [[European Union]].[http://www.trecers.net/downloads/med-csp_en.pdf Report on Solar Power Potential] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927023047/http://www.trecers.net/downloads/med-csp_en.pdf |date=2007-09-27 }}, German Aerospace Center === Algeria === {{main|Solar power in Algeria}} Algeria has the highest technical and economical potential for solar power exploitation in the MENA region, with about 170 TWh per year. First industrial scale solar thermal power project has been initiated by inauguration of Hassi R'Mel power station in 2011. This new hybrid power plant combines a 25-megawatt (MW) concentrating solar power array in conjunction with a 130 MW combined cycle gas turbine plant. In addition, Algeria has launched in 2011 a national program to develop renewable energy based on photovoltaics (PV), concentrated solar power (CSP) and wind power, and to promote energy efficiency. The program consists of installing up to 12 GW of power generating capacity from renewable sources to meet the domestic electricity demand by 2030. === Morocco === {{main|Solar power in Morocco}} Solar power in Morocco is enabled by the country having one of the highest rates of solar [[insolation]] among other countries— about 3,000 hours per year of sunshine but up to 3,600 hours in the desert. [[Morocco]] has launched one of the world's largest solar energy projects costing an estimated $9 billion. The aim of the project is to create 2,000 megawatts of solar generation capacity by the year 2020.[http://www.constructionweekonline.com/article-16983-afdb-helps-fund-144bn-moroccan-solar-project/ AfDB helps fund $1.44bn Moroccan solar project] Five solar power stations are to be constructed, including both [[photovoltaic]] and [[concentrated solar power]] technology. The Moroccan Agency for Solar Energy (MASEN), a public-private venture, has been established to lead the project. The first plant will be commissioned in 2015,[http://ecogeek.org/component/content/article/3770 Morocco Building 500 MW Solar Power Project] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140924062425/http://ecogeek.org/component/content/article/3770 |date=2014-09-24 }} and the entire project in 2020. Once completed, the solar project will provide 38% of Morocco's annual electricity generation. === Somalia === {{main|Solar power in Somalia}} === South Africa === {{main|Solar power in South Africa}} South Africa had 1329 MW of PV installations and 100 MW of concentrating solar thermal at the end of 2016. It is expected to reach an installed capacity 8,400 MW by 2030, along with 8,400 MW of [[wind power]].[http://www.evwind.es/noticias.php?id_not=17693 Solar energy in South Africa] The country's insolation greatly exceeds the average values in Europe, Russia, and most of North America.{{Cite web |url=http://www.solarstreetscapes.com/gallery79052.cfm?startrow=9 |title=Insolation maps, retrieved April 14, 2012 |access-date=August 10, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140603131338/http://www.solarstreetscapes.com/gallery79052.cfm?startrow=9 |archive-date=June 3, 2014 |url-status=dead |df=mdy-all }} == Asia == === China === {{main|Solar power in China}} [[File:China Photovoltaics Installed Capacity 2016.png|thumb|China's installed solar PV]] China is leading the world in solar PV generation, with the total installed capacity exceeding 100 GW. China is the world's largest market for both [[photovoltaics]] and [[solar thermal energy]]. and in the last few years, more than half of the total PV additions came from the country. Solar power in the People's Republic of China is one of the biggest industries and the subsidies by the government have helped in bringing down the cost of solar power, not only in China, but the whole world. Three of the top four [[List of photovoltaic power stations|largest photovoltaic power stations]] in operation are located in China, including the world's largest Tengger Desert Solar Park. China also leads the world in [[solar water heating]] with 290 [[GWth]] in operation at the end of 2014, accounting for about 70% of the total world capacity. China's goal is to reach 1,300 GW of Solar Capacity by 2050. === India === [[File:Jawaharlal Nehru National Solar Mission Solarishi.jpg|thumb|National Solar Mission in India]] [[File:India Photovoltaics Installed Capacity.svg|thumb|India's installed solar PV capacity]] {{main|Solar power in India}} India has the world's third fastest expanding solar power program (next only to China & USA). In the year 2017 alone India added a record 9,255 MW of solar power with another 9,627 MW of solar projects under development.https://www.pv-tech.org/news/india-added-9255mw-of-solar-in-2017-bridge-to-india{{Cite news|url=https://www.greentechmedia.com/articles/read/solar-trends-2018-gtm-research#gs.wcf=9TI|title=10 Trends That Will Shape the Global Solar Market in 2018|access-date=2018-02-06}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.theenergycollective.com/tim-buckley/2423742/cheap-renewables-transforming-global-electricity-business|title=Cheap Renewables Are Transforming the Global Electricity Business - The Energy Collective|date=2018-02-16|work=The Energy Collective|access-date=2018-02-21|language=en-GB}} India launched its [[Jawaharlal Nehru National Solar Mission|National Solar Mission]] in 2010 under the National Action Plan on Climate Change, with plans to generate 20 GW by 2022. announced an initiative to increase the solar capacity to 100 GW{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/india-solar/indias-modi-raises-solar-investment-target-to-100-bln-by-2022-idUSL3N0UG13H20150102|title=India's Modi raises solar investment target to $100 bln by 2022|date=2015-01-02|work=Reuters|accessdate=2018-02-04}} and total renewable power capacity to 175 gigawatts (GW) by 2022. This target is ambitious considering the worldwide installed solar capacity at that time was 177 GW, out of which only 2.5 GW was installed in India. To reach the goal of 100 GW of installed solar capacity by 2022, Modi's government has set a target to auction at least 77 gigawatts of additional solar power capacity by March 2020.{{Cite web|url=https://cleantechnica.com/2017/11/13/india-plans-worlds-largest-solar-power-tender-20-gigawatts/|title=India Plans World's Largest Solar Power Tender -- 20 Gigawatts {{!}} CleanTechnica|website=cleantechnica.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-02-04}} A total of 1.2 GW of solar power is tendered in the first week of 2018 and a solar power tender of 20 GW, world's largest so far, is to be auctioned off in one go in 2018. Several large grid-scale solar parks are in operation, several of which are among the [[List of photovoltaic power stations#World's largest photovoltaic power stations|world's largest]] such as [[Kurnool Ultra Mega Solar Park]] with the capacity of 1,000 MW, the Kamuthi Solar Power Project with the capacity of 648 MW, the 345 MW [[Charanka Solar Park]], the 480 MW [[Bhadla Solar Park]] with a proposed capacity of 2,255 MW and the [[Gujarat]] solar parks with a combined capacity of 605 MW.[http://www.energyinsight.info/gujarat_charanka_solar_park.html Gujarat's Charanka Solar Park] In July 2017, Indian Railways rolled out trains with rooftop solar to power the lights, fans and displays inside the coaches.{{Cite solar-panelled train that will save 21,000 litres of diesel a year|date=2017-07-19|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-02-11|language=en-GB}} Cochin International Airport, seventh busiest in India, is the first one in the world to run entirely on solar power,{{Cite journal|date=2017-07-01|title=Fully solar powered airport: A case study of Cochin International airport|journal=Journal of Air Transport Management|language=en|volume=62|pages=176–188|doi=10.1016/j.jairtraman.2017.04.004|issn=0969-6997|last1=Sukumaran|first1=Sreenath|last2=Sudhakar|first2=K.|url=http://umpir.ump.edu.my/id/eprint/18178/1/Fully%20solar%20powered%20airport.pdf}}{{Cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/03/14/technology/india-cochin-solar-powered-airport/index.html|title=The first world's first solar-powered airport is in Cochin, India|last=Mullen|first=Jethro|work=CNNMoney|access-date=2018-02-06}} handling more than 1,000 flights a week. Similarly, the Union Territory of Diu is fully run by solar power.{{Cite news|url=https://www.care2.com/causes/indian-district-becomes-first-union-territory-to-run-entirely-on-solar-power.html|title=Indian District Becomes First Union Territory to Run Entirely on Solar Power {{!}} Care2 Causes|work=Care2 Causes|access-date=2018-03-18|language=en-US}} Solar power features prominently in Modi government's US$2.5 billion SAUBHAGYA scheme launched in July 2015 to electrify every Indian household by 2019 — a huge task considering around 300 million people were without electricity. The use of local mini-grids run on solar power is “a big part of the push, with 60 percent of new connections expected to be to renewable power", according to a report by the International Energy Agency.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-india-solarpower-women/solar-power-push-lights-up-options-for-indias-rural-women-idUSKBN1FW0LI|title=Solar power push lights up options for India's rural women|date=2018-02-12|work=Reuters|accessdate=2018-02-18}} The government provides subsidy of up to 90% of the upfront capital cost to install solar-powered water pumping systems for irrigation and drinking water.[32] As of 30 November 2017, more than 142,000 solar pumps have been installed to irrigate the agricultural fields.[33] This scheme weans farmers away from diesel-powered pumps and generates extra income for them by allowing to sell surplus power to the grid. It is one of the innovative ways that the government is empowering the rural population with the help of solar energy by addressing specific issues such as water availability. The solar panels are being built over the irrigation canals to preserve water from evaporation in drought-prone sunny areas. The world's first canal-top solar project was set up on Narmada in Gujarat in 2012. For the last mile connectivity in remote and inaccessible areas, the government provides solar power packs of 200 to 300 watt-peak (Wp), along with battery bank, that includes five LED lights, one DC fan and one DC power plug.[34] Other schemes includes Solar Street Light Scheme, providing solar direct current lighting systems, solar lanterns, solar cookers, etc. In January 2016, the Prime Minister of India, [[Narendra Modi]], and the former President of France, [[François Hollande]], laid the foundation stone for the headquarters of the [[Sunshine countries|International Solar Alliance]] (ISA) in Gwalpahari, India, an alliance of 121 countries, announced at the Paris COP21 climate summit.{{Cite news|url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/energy/power/pm-narendra-modi-and-french-president-francois-hollande-to-launch-game-changing-solar-alliance/articleshow/49975568.cms|title=PM Narendra Modi and French President Francois Hollande to launch game changing solar alliance|last=Goswami|first=Urmi|date=2015-11-30|work=The Economic Times|access-date=2018-02-11}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.firstpost.com/world/international-solar-alliance-sign-of-indias-leadership-on-global-stage-say-experts-2528060.html|title=International Solar Alliance sign of India's leadership on global stage, say experts - Firstpost|website=firstpost.com|access-date=2018-02-11}} The [[International Solar Alliance|ISA]] focuses on promoting and developing solar energy and reducing production and development costs through wider deployment of solar technologies in the developing world.{{Cite news|url=http://www.alternet.org/environment/india-unveils-global-solar-alliance-120-countries-paris-climate-summit|title=India Unveils Global Solar Alliance of 120 Countries at Paris Climate Summit|last=Neslen|first=Arthur|date=2015-12-04|newspaper=AlterNet|access-date=2016-08-06}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/news/world/paris-climate-meet-indialed-global-solar-alliance-to-counter-developed-nations/article7916353.ece|title=Paris climate meet: India-led global solar alliance to counter developed nations|work=@businessline|access-date=2018-02-11|language=en}} On June 30, 2016, the alliance entered into a partnership with the [[World Bank]] for accelerating mobilization of finance for solar energy — an estimated US$1000 billion in investments that will be needed by 2030, to meet [[International Solar Alliance|ISA]]'s goals for the massive deployment of affordable solar energy worldwide. At the World Future Energy Summit (WFES) held in Abu Dhabi in January 2018, the government of India announced the setting up of a $350 million solar development fund to enable financing of solar projects. Prime Minister [[Narendra Modi]] promoted solar energy during the plenary speech at [[World Economic Forum]] annual meet in Davos in 2018 and invited investments in the sector in India promising ease of doing business.{{Cite news|url=http://www.livemint.com/Politics/zoGD1tD80dF755GW9xZkyJ/Narendra-Modi-in-Davos-LIVE-PM-to-address-World-Economic-Fo.html|title=WEF Davos 2018 highlights: Narendra Modi warns of three global threats|last=Livemint|date=2018-01-23|work=livemint.com/|access-date=2018-02-08}} Modi's ambitious plan when announced in the leading up to the Paris COP21 climate summit received much skepticism and the government's strategy to scale-up the renewable energy by relying on competitive bidding to reduce the cost was regarded as infeasible. However, starting around 2016–2017, new renewable energy became cheaper to build than running existing coal-fired plants in India. As of January 2018, 65% of coal power generation in India is being sold at higher rates than new renewable energy bids in competitive power auctions.{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/energyinnovation/2018/01/30/india-coal-power-is-about-to-crash-65-of-existing-coal-costs-more-than-new-wind-and-solar/#640dd3104c0f|title=India Coal Power Is About To Crash: 65% Of Existing Coal Costs More Than New Wind And Solar|last=Technology|first=Energy Innovation: Policy and|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-02-25|language=en}} India has scrapped tenders for coal-fired power stations and around 80% of new coal-fired power plants under planning have been halted or canceled.{{Cite news|url=https://asia.nikkei.com/Business/Trends/Renewable-energy-rise-forces-layoffs-at-Mitsubishi-Hitachi-Power|title=Renewable energy rise forces layoffs at Mitsubishi Hitachi Power|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180127042701/https://asia.nikkei.com/Business/Trends/Renewable-energy-rise-forces-layoffs-at-Mitsubishi-Hitachi-Power|archive-date=2018-01-27|url-status=dead}} In the month of May 2017 alone, plans for building coal power for nearly 14 GW – about the same as the total amount in the UK – were canceled on account of declining solar costs.{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/environment/india-solar-power-electricity-cancels-coal-fired-power-stations-record-low-a7751916.html|title=India just cancelled 14 huge coal-fired power stations as solar energy prices hit record low|date=2017-05-23|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-02-06|language=en-GB}} Analyst Tim Buckley said “Measures taken by the Indian Government to improve energy efficiency coupled with ambitious renewable energy targets and the plummeting cost of solar has had an impact on existing as well as proposed coal fired power plants, rendering an increasing number as financially unviable. India’s solar tariffs have literally been free falling in recent months."{{Cite web|url=http://ieefa.org/ieefa-asia-indias-electricity-sector-transformation-happening-now/|title=IEEFA Asia: India's Electricity-Sector Transformation Is Happening Now - Institute for Energy Economics & Financial Analysis : Institute for Energy Economics & Financial Analysis|website=ieefa.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-02-06}} As reported by NYTimes in May 2017, "According to research released last week at a United Nations climate meeting in Germany, China and India should easily exceed the targets they set for themselves in the 2015 Paris Agreement..... India is now expected to obtain 40 percent of its electricity from non-fossil fuel sources by 2022, eight years ahead of schedule."{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/22/opinion/paris-agreement-climate-china-india.html|title=Opinion {{!}} China and India Make Big Strides on Climate Change|last=Board|first=The Editorial|date=2017-05-22|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-02-04|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/coal-india-closes-37-mines-solar-power-sustainable-energy-market-influence-pollution-a7800631.html|title=The world's biggest coal company just shut down 37 mines because they are not economically viable anymore|date=2017-06-21|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-02-11|language=en-GB}} === Japan === {{Main|Solar power in Japan}} Solar power in [[Japan]] has been expanding since the late 1990s. By the end of 2017, cumulative installed PV capacity reached over 50 GW with nearly 8 GW installed in the year 2017. The country is a leading manufacturer of solar panels and is in the top 4 ranking for countries with the most solar PV installed. The increase in registrations mostly happened in December and was attributed to a reduction in feed-in tariffs starting from 2018 (from US$0.13 to US$0.10). === Ukraine === {{main|Solar power in Ukraine}} === United Kingdom === {{main|Solar power in the United Kingdom}} At the end of 2011, there were 230,000 solar power projects in the United Kingdom,{{cite news |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2012/02/09/uk-solar-tariff-idUKTRE8180XS20120209 |title=UK wants sustained cuts to solar panel tariffs |author=Yeganeh Torbati |date=Feb 9, 2012 |work=Reuters }} with a total installed generating capacity of 750 [[megawatts]] (MW).{{cite web |url=http://www.epia.org/index.php?id=18 |title=Market Report 2011 |author=European Photovoltaic Industry Association |year=2012 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140702040515/http://www.epia.org/index.php?id=18 |archivedate=2014-07-02 }} By February 2012 the installed capacity had reached 1,000 MW.{{cite web |url= |title=UK hits one GW of PV capacity |author=Jonathan Gifford |date=23 February 2012 |work=PV Magazine }} [[Solar power]] use has increased very rapidly in recent years, albeit from a small base, as a result of reductions in the cost of [[photovoltaic]] (PV) panels, and the introduction of a [[Feed-in tariff]] (FIT) subsidy in April 2010. As of April 2015, PV capacity had risen to 6,562 MW across 698,860 installations.{{cite web |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/statistics/solar-photovoltaics-deployment|title=Gov.UK Statistics - Solar photovoltaics deployment|date=May 28, 2015|author=Department of Energy & Climate Change}} The latest government figures indicates UK solar photovoltaic (PV) generation capacity has reached 12,404 MW in December 2017.{{Cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/statistics/solar-photovoltaics-deployment|title=Solar photovoltaics deployment - GOV.UK|website=gov.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-02-21}} ==Americas== ===Brazil=== {{main|Solar power in Brazil}} ===Canada=== {{main|Solar power in Canada}} [[Sarnia Photovoltaic Power Plant]] near [[Sarnia]], [[Ontario]], was in September 2010 the [[List of photovoltaic power stations|world's largest]] [[photovoltaic plant]] with an [[installed capacity]] of 80 [[Watt-peak|MWp]].[http://www.cbc.ca/technology/story/2010/10/04/sarnia-enbridge-solar-farm.html Enbridge completes Sarnia solar farm] Retrieved 5 October 2010 until surpassed by a plant in China. The Sarnia plant covers {{convert|950|acre}} and contains about 10.3 million sq feet / 966,000 square metres (96.6 ha), which is about 1.3 million thin film panels. The expected annual energy yield is about 120,000 MW·h, which if produced in a coal-fired plant would require emission of 39,000 tonnes of CO2 per year. Canada has many regions that are sparsely populated and difficult to access, but also does not have optimal access to sunlight given the high latitudes of much of the country. Photovoltaic cells are increasingly used as standalone units, mostly as off-grid distributed electricity generation to power remote homes, telecommunications equipment, oil and pipeline monitoring stations and navigational devices. The Canadian PV market has grown quickly and Canadian companies make solar modules, controls, specialized water pumps, high efficiency refrigerators and solar lighting systems.{{cite web |title=Another Sunny Year for Solar Power |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725035832/http://worldwatch.org/node/5449 |archivedate=25 July 2011|url=http://worldwatch.org/node/5449}} Ontario has subsidized solar power energy to promote its growth. One of the most important uses for PV cells is in northern communities, many of which depend on high-cost [[diesel fuel]] to generate electricity. Since the 1970s, the federal government and industry has encouraged the development of solar technologies for these communities. Some of these efforts have focused on the use of hybrid systems that provide power 24 hours a day, using solar power when sunlight is available, in combination with another energy source. ===Chile=== {{main|Solar power in Chile}} The 246MW El Romero solar photovoltaic plant open in November 2016 at [[Vallenar]] in the Atacama region[http://en.mercopress.com/2016/11/14/chile-connects-latin-america-s-largest-solar-plant-to-the-national-grid Chile connects Latin America's largest solar plant to the national grid], MercoPress, November 14th 2016 It was the largest solar farm in Latin America when it opened. It is planning a [[solar trough]] based plant with 30 MW which will use a [[combined cycle]] gas turbine about 400 MW to provide electricity to the city of Agua Prieta, Sonora. To date, the World Bank has given US$50 million to finance this project. {{cite web |url= http://www.earth-policy.org/datacenter/xls/indicator12_2010_6.xls |title=Cumulative and Newly-Installed Solar Photovoltaics Capacity in Ten Leading Countries and the World, 2009 |author= |publisher=[[Earth Policy Institute]] |date=2010-09-21 |accessdate=2010-09-22}} ===United States=== {{main|Solar power in the United States}} {{multiple image |direction = horizontal |align = right |width = 185 |image1=Solar Plant kl.jpg |image2=Barack Obama speaks at Nellis AFB 2009-05-27 2.jpg |caption1=The [[SEGS]] CSS plant in [[San Bernardino County, California]] was built in the 1980s. |caption2=U.S. President [[Barack Obama]] addressed an audience at the [[Nellis Solar Power Plant|Nellis]] in May 2009. }} Solar power in the United States includes utility-scale [[solar power plants]] as well as local [[distributed generation]], mostly from rooftop [[photovoltaics]]. Installations have been growing rapidly in recent years as costs have declined with the U.S. hitting 76 [[Gigawatt|GW]] of installed solar PV capacity at the end of 2019.{{cite news |url= https://www.greentechmedia.com/articles/read/the-us-residential-solar-market-got-its-mojo-back-in-2019|title= The US Built 13.3GW of Solar Last Year as the Residential Market Regained Its Stride |publisher= Greentech Media|date= March 17, 2020 |accessdate= April 28, 2020 }} The United States is in the top 4 ranking for countries with the most solar PV installed. The American [[Solar Energy Industries Association]] projects that total solar PV capacity will reach over 100 GW by 2021.{{cite news |url= http://www.seia.org/news/us-solar-market-set-grow-119-2016-installations-reach-16-gw|title= Solar Market Set to Grow 119% in 2016, Installations to Reach 16 GW|publisher= Solar Energy Industries Association|date= March 9, 2016 |accessdate= March 11, 2016 }} Electrical generation has been rising in tandem with capacity as U.S. [[Energy Information Administration]] data show that utility-scale solar power generated 1.8% of total U.S. electricity in 2019, up from <0.1% in 2005.{{cite news |url= https://www.eia.gov/tools/faqs/faq.php?id=427&t=3|title= What is U.S. electricity generation by energy source?|publisher= U.S. Energy Information Administration|date= February 27, 2020 |accessdate= April 28, 2020 }}US Energy Information Administration, [http://www.eia.gov/electricity/monthly/epm_table_grapher.cfm?t=epmt_1_1_a Table 1.1.A. Net Generation by Other Renewable Sources: Total (All Sectors), 2005-December 2015], [http://www.eia.gov/electricity/monthly/epm_table_grapher.cfm?t=epmt_1_1 Table 1.1. Net Generation by Energy Source: Total (All Sectors), 2005-December 2015], accessed 11. Mar 2016. This figure is even higher in certain states, already reaching over 10% of generation in five states (California, Hawaii, Nevada, Massachusetts, and Vermont).{{cite news |url= https://www.seia.org/states-map|title= Solar State By State (Q4 2019 data)|publisher= Solar Energy Industries Association|date= March 2020 |accessdate= April 28, 2020 }} The United States conducted much early research in photovoltaics and concentrated solar power and is among the top countries in the world in deploying the technology, [[List of photovoltaic power stations#World's largest photovoltaic power stations|being home to 4 of the 10 largest utility-scale photovoltaic power stations in the world]] as of 2017. The energy resource continues to be encouraged through official policy with 29 states having set mandatory [[Renewable portfolio standard|renewable energy targets]] as of October 2015, solar power being specifically included in 20 of them.{{cite news |url = http://ncsolarcen-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/Renewable-Portfolio-Standards.pdf |title = Renewable Portfolio Standard Policies - October 2015 |publisher = Database of State Incentives for Renewables & Efficiency |date = October 2015 |accessdate = March 11, 2016 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160312073518/http://ncsolarcen-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/Renewable-Portfolio-Standards.pdf |archive-date = 2016-03-12 |url-status = dead}}{{cite news |url = http://ncsolarcen-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/RPS-carveout-map2.pdf |title = Renewable Portfolio Standards (RPS) with Solar or Distributed Generation Provisions - August 2015 |publisher = Database of State Incentives for Renewables & Efficiency |date = August 2015 |accessdate = March 11, 2016 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150919071704/http://ncsolarcen-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/RPS-carveout-map2.pdf |archive-date = 2015-09-19 |url-status = dead}} Aside from utility projects, roughly 784,000 homes and businesses in the nation have installed solar systems through the second quarter of 2015.{{cite news|url= http://www.seia.org/research-resources/solar-industry-data|title= Solar Industry Data|publisher= Solar Energy Industries Association|date= September 2015 |accessdate= March 11, 2016 }} ==Oceania== A number of Pacific island states have committed to high percentages of renewable energy use, both to serve as an example to other countries and to cut the high costs of imported fuels. A number of solar installations have been financed and assisted by Japan, New Zealand and the United Arab Emirates. Solar farms have gone online in [[Renewable energy in Tuvalu|Tuvalu]], [[Fiji]] and [[Kiribati]].[http://www.thenational.ae/business/energy/masdar-and-new-zealand-to-develop-solar-plant-in-solomon-islands Masdar and New Zealand to develop solar plant in Solomon Islands], ''The National'' (Abu Dhabi), October 23, 2015 UAE-Pacific Partnership Fund solar projects completed by [[Masdar]] in 2016 included: 1MW in the [[Solomon Islands]], 500 kW in [[Nauru]], 600 kW in the [[Marshall Islands]], 600 kW in [[Federated States of Micronesia|Micronesia]] and a 450 kW solar-diesel hybrid plant in [[Palau]].[http://www.thenational.ae/business/energy/masdar-completes-five-solar-and-wind-projects-in-the-pacific Masdar completes five solar and wind projects in the Pacific], ''The National'', Abu Dhabi Media, LeAnne Graves, May 17, 2016[https://www.wam.ae/en/news/emirates/1395295579132.html UAE-Pacific Partnership Fund accomplishes 11 clean energy projects delivered by Masdar] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160517105738/http://www.wam.ae/en/news/emirates/1395295579132.html |date=2016-05-17 }}, Emirates News Agency, 17 May 2016 American Samoa has 2 MW of solar installed at Pago Pago Airport.[http://www.radionz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/279857/american-samoa-embracing-more-solar-power American Samoa embracing more solar power], Radio New Zealand, 28 July 2015 ===Australia=== {{main|Solar power in Australia}} [[File:Broken Hill solar plant aerial.jpg|thumb|upright=1.35|[[Broken Hill Solar Plant]], New South Wales]] Australia had over 13,904 megawatts (MW) of installed photovoltaic (PV) solar power by September 2019.{{cite web|url=http://pv-map.apvi.org.au/analyses|title=Australian PV market since April 2001|work=apvi.org.au}} The largest solar power station in [[Australia]] is the 220 MW [[Bungala Solar Power Project|Bungala]] solar plant. Other significant solar arrays include the 168 Daydream Solar Farm, 150 MW Coleambally Solar Farm, 124 MW [[Sun Metals Solar Farm]] and the 110 MW [[Darling Downs Solar Farm]]. A 9 MWe (megawatts, electrical) solar thermal `coal saver' system was constructed at Liddell power station. The system used `compact linear Fresnel reflector' technology developed in Australia. It provided solar-powered steam to the 600 MW black coal power station's boiler [[feedwater heater]]. By 2016, it was "effectively" closed and an effort to build a similar 40 MW solar boost at Kogan Creek coal power station was stopped.[http://reneweconomy.com.au/2016/cs-energy-pulls-plug-on-worlds-largest-solar-booster-project-16737 CS Energy pulls plug on world's largest "solar booster" project], Renew Economy, Giles Parkinson, 21 March 2016 ===New Zealand=== {{main|Solar power in New Zealand}} Solar power in New Zealand currently only generates 0.1 percent of New Zealand's electricity since more emphasis has been placed on hydroelectric, geothermal, and wind power in New Zealand's push for renewable energy. Solar power systems were installed in 42 schools in New Zealand in the Schoolgen program, a program developed by [[Genesis Energy Limited|Genesis Energy]] to educate students in solar power. Each participating school has a 2 kW solar panel. Between February 2007 and 29 December 29, 2012, 395.714 MWh were produced.[http://www.schoolgen.co.nz/ Schoolgen] In 2010, New Zealand's largest thin film solar array was the 20 kW array installed at Hubbard Foods{{Cite web |url=http://www.hubbards.co.nz/vector.aspx |title=Vector Hubbards Solar Panels |access-date=2013-11-30 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130208191029/http://hubbards.co.nz/Vector.aspx |archive-date=2013-02-08 |url-status=dead }} A 21.6 kW photovoltaic array was installed in [[Queenstown, New Zealand|Queenstown]] in 2009.[http://www.sunnyportal.com/Templates/PublicPageOverview.aspx?plant=796132fc-e1a3-448e-8f43-7c7dee64bc73&splang=en-US Speargrass Domain Plant Profile] In April 2012, New Zealand's largest solar power plant was the 68.4 kW array installed to meet 70% of the electricity needs of South Auckland Forging Engineering Ltd, which is expected to pay for itself in eight to nine years.[http://demm.co.nz/articles/new-zealand%E2%80%99s-largest-solar-power-plant New Zealand's largest solar power plant]Excess power will be purchased at the sale price for two years, otherwise known as net metering. == See also == {{Portal|Energy|Renewable energy}} *[[List of photovoltaic power stations]] *[[List of solar thermal power stations]] *[[Growth of photovoltaics]] *[[Renewable energy]] *[[Renewable energy commercialization]] *[[Solar energy]] *[[Solar thermal energy]] *[[International Solar Alliance]] == References == {{Reflist|refs= {{cite web|url=http://www.iea-pvps.org/fileadmin/dam/public/report/statistics/IEA-PVPS_-_A_Snapshot_of_Global_PV_-_1992-2017.pdf|title=2018 Snapshot of Global Photovoltaic Markets|publisher=[[International Energy Agency]]|year=2018|id=Report IEA PVPS T1-33:2018}} }} {{Solar power by country}} {{Renewable energy by country}} [[Category:Solar power by country| ]] [[Category:Renewable energy]]
